question.name: 16.5.2.2 Example Maclaurin expansion
question.questiontext:
Example

Find the Maclaurin expansion of \(\cos x\).

Solution

Here \(f(x)=\cos x\) and, differentiating a number of times: \[f(x)=\cos x,\qquad f'(x)=-\sin x,\qquad f''(x)=-\cos x,\qquad f'''(x)=\sin x\quad \text{etc.}\] Evaluating each of these at \(x=0\): \[ f(0)=1,\quad f'(0)=0,\quad f''(0)=-1,\quad f'''(0)=0\ \text{etc.}\] Substituting into \(f(x)=f(0)+xf'(0)+\dfrac{x^2}{2!}f''(0)+\dfrac{x^3}{3!}f'''(0)+\cdots\), gives : \[\cos x=1-\dfrac{x^2}{2!}+\dfrac{x^4}{4!}-\dfrac{x^6}{6!}+\cdots\] Confirm (by finding the radius of convergence) that this series is convergent for all values of \(x\).
